comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I think this is Chong-Hsu Henry Wang, a Yale undergraduate who won the university's junior class Ten Eyck prize for speaking in March, 1915. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9806E7DA1238E633A... His speech warned of Japan's aggressive intentions toward China: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C04E5D61439EF32A... He graduated Yale in 1916 and received a Masters from Princeton in 1917. books.google.com/books?id=2DJLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA452&d... In September, 1921 (the date on the negative at upper left), a C.H. Wang came to the U.S. as Chief Justice of the Chinese Supreme Court and delegate to the Washington conference on disarmament and Far East questions, and as a member of a committee to revise the League of Nations covenant. However, this C.H. Wang is apparently Wang Chung-hui. books.google.com/books?id=K6EqAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA237&l... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B06E6DE1431EF33A...

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: artolog:  Thanks for identifying Wang for us.  It seems likely this is the same person.  We'll include some of your information next time we update the description.
